Notably bad was the dumbing-down of what I assume was intended to be an "East End" gangland script, ably supplemented and portrayed by Dexter Fletcher - sadly destroyed (ironically, since he is actually Camden-born) by the wooden-ness of Max Iron's delivery. To be fair to Max - he clearly spoke the script as provided - so I'll have to put the blame on the screen writer. Margot Robbie's part to play gets a 6 out of 10 (sorry - the accent wobbling all over the place was way too distracing!), Simon Pegg gets an 8 for a solid performance, with Mike Myers coming in around an 8, too (bearing in mind we know Mike has roots in the UK, so it's all good!)

I enjoyed this film as a quirky piece which has some stand out moments. The all-too-sudden lapse into gore was a little disappointing and, as others have commented, that finale tied all of the lose ends together but, ultimately, lacked "closure". I gave it a 7 - it could've been an 8 if I wasn't so distracted by Margot's accent which, if you're not British, won't bother you in the slightest!

The first hour and a quarter of the movie I was wondering what in the hell was it about, but the remaining fifteen minutes everything makes sense, though it doesn't mean an improvement.

There is a twist, well more than one actually, but as many can be predictible, there is one that took me by surprise.

Margot Robbie try so hard but I just don't believe her femme fatale, she feels so Harley Quinn, speaking of which, the film is like a lame attempt of style from Guy Ritchie films with some Suicide Squad on top , with a bad use of neonish photography.

There is no ovation for any actor or actress in this one, much less the messy direction from Vaughn Stein, which I think was way too ambitious on his directional debut.

Nevertheless, Terminal is not an unwatchable film, there might be a slight chance to be liked by a few because is not so pointless after all, just maybe too overcooked.

Like seriously.. i'm planning to suicide after watching this movie!

Really really disappointed.

review_title: Only the final 10 minutes were perfect...
review_detailed_main:
Two killers on a sinister mission, a terminally ill teacher, an enigmatic janitor and a waitress with a double life. Their lives intersect and their fate will be decided by a criminal mastermind who expects revenge. It follows the trajectory of several characters: two assassins with a sinister mission, a professor with a fatal illness, an enigmatic janitor and a waitress with a double life.

Trying to like it, trying to follow along, trying to connect, but it's not being so easy and fun... It's not bad, the plot is slow, very slow, the second half takes a breath with the unfolding of the facts and the function and past of each characters , I like dark humor and cold irony, but they are not enough to make us fall in love, a light pastime, it just passes... Only the final 10 minutes were perfect...
Basically Margot Robbie is annoying AF in this show. Couldn't stand more than one episode

review_title: Well acted, beautifully shot but thats all.
review_detailed_main:
The film hardly gets 6/10.

Acting was good to superb by almost every cast member. Most scenes where beautifully shot (superb lighting by the way) but thats it.

Style over substance with a script containing plot holes the size of manhattan. Actually the entire film could have been a music video clip. There are films that style matters (remember Sin City?), they actually had a solid story too.

Blame the writer(s) for this one.

The storytelling of this movie couldn't be worse. Characters are just there, no context given and most of the time (before I turned it off after about one hour) I was wondering whats going on. just dialogs seemingly going nowhere... in the beginning it got me curious, but after half an hour I got annoyed, gave it another while and turned it off happily.

The style was way over the top, the colouring and lighting just way too much. should have put the effort into the character development.
Thr movie is supposed to be a neo noir but comes across as an unfunny comedy. It's neither intelligent nor exciting and it feels about twice as long as it really is. My advice is:Avoid.
Super enjoyable.... Very clever and fill of surprises ... Hope this director gets his due AND continues making great movies like THIS 👍👍👍

One of the worst, meaningless scenario that I've ever seen. But when you try to look from a different perspective, an angle for criticizing only cinematography and pure acting, I think that's is the secret sauce of this film. Trying to change the components and breaking the barriers of the movie structure. Showing, tend to tell the interactions by odd dialogues and wieldy colors. This quotient of the film is seductive and that is the reason why I gave 3.5 out of 5.

review_title: Reminds me of Black Mirror... In that I just want it to end.
review_detailed_main:
I loved John Wick 1 & 2. I greatly enjoyed Atomic Blonde. I love Tarantino flicks and I am excited as Guy Ritchie releases each new outing. Hell, I even greatly enjoy stories inspired by Alice in Wonerland. I've loved to watch Simon Pegg since Spaced. Mike Myers needs a comeback. And Margot Robbie makes for a stunning femme fatale.

Why do I bring this up? Well... Because, simply. This film had all the right elements. And a great cinematographer who I hope gets great gigs from this. The only thing it doesn't have... Is a script worthy of the pieces it's built around. It wants to be a clever noir filled with chocking twists and turns. But after 30 minutes all twists were severely telegraphed and by the hour mark all threads were effectively over and done with. But this director decides to wave the script in my face and prance around with endless montages of stuff we've already figured out just to show me how clever he is and... because he had to pad it out to a contractually obligated 90 minutes.

In that way it reminds me of Black Mirror. A lot of effort put into an uninspired mess. And after half of the story ImI groaning at the screen JUST BLOODY END ALREADY!

Simon Pegg was a delight as always though.

....and nothing happens. It looked promising, we get the whole "Sin City package " of neon lights, dark hallways, guns and briefcases and lap dancers, Margot Robbie looking cool in different outfits and Simone Pegg dodging awkward situations... yet nothing really happens and instead we get quick cuts and flashbacks and main characters meeting up exchanging supposedly witty and clever dialogues, that are not that witty nor clever. So I decided to quit. Who knows maybe the rest of the film is a Masterpiece, and maybe the beginning is crucial for the plot...judge for yourselves. I gave up.

review_title: Margot is very talented, but this movie not so much
review_detailed_main:
I have been waiting for Margot to find that role that allows her to exude her full ability as an actress. I thought that Harley Quinn would be it, and it should have been, but they didnt let her loose and the script was lame. This movie was similar, it suggested alot, promised much, tried to deliver, but not quite. Being a brit though, i was surprised how well down she had the accent. Not just the voice either, the way she speaks, moves her mouth, had me convinced.

Movie is better than its current IMDB rating for sure, but its trying to be something and not quite coming together, lacks a punch.

I watched this randomly on Amazon Prime because I was searching for a Jack Nicholson film and, predictably, other films came up in the results too, including this one and it was the last day it was on Prime. So, I took a chance and, despite widely varying reviews, decided to give it a go. MISTAKE ! ! My god .. What a stinker of a movie. It's atrocious. 😝 The storyline is crap, the settings are murky and annoying, Margot Robbie's attempt at a British accent was laughable and it was all over the place, the Alice in Wonderland references are repetitive and boring and ...well, need I go on?! Just AWFUL. I only suffered my way through it in the hope that, somehow, it would get better along the way. IT DIDN'T!! Ironically, about 5 minutes from the end my laptop froze and I had to go back to the internet when it unfroze, by which time the film had run out on Amazon Prime (to see it for free) so I then would have had to pay to see the ending! Because I'd almost given up the will to live at that point as the film had bored me almost to death I couldn't have given a damn about those last few minutes and was just glad to get it off my laptop screen!

Not in a million years could I recommend such a sh** movie!
I definitely will have bad dream tonight.its is a good criminal film but it's dark basic color will be too scary

Blatant Tarantino rip-off. I was hopeful with the combination of actors but was more disappointed as the movie went on. The hand gestures, the dialogue, the scene structure, the reverse chronology, the overall atmosphere are all just low-rate imitation. I love Tarantino, so I suppose that's why I gave this film 4 stars. I understand that people are influenced by others' work, and QT himself does a lot of things similar to some his film idols, but this is ridiculous. It's like they chopped up a few of his films and made an awful plagiaristic collage. I feel like even the actors knew deep down, and the performances suffered because of it.

review_title: The Usual Suspects, The Prestige, Pulp Fiction and Nighthawks haphazardly quilted into one movie
review_detailed_main:
Visually beautiful, entertaining, lacking depth, cohesion and originality.

This film is a constant tip of the hat to Edward Hopper and his "Nighthawks", Christopher McQuarrie's Keyser Söze, Luc Besson's Matilda or Nikkita, Tarantino's "Pulp Fiction", Lewis Carroll's "Alice in Wonderland, and Jonathan Nolan's and Christopher Nolan's "The Prestige".

Unfortunately by minute 7 of the film, the poor choice of casting of a heavily made-up Mike Myers, immediately gives away the "first" climax of the movie (don't worry, the makeup is so plastic that I'm confident I'm not giving anything away here). I stayed because of the lovely Hopperesque photography, for the beautiful custom designs and for my affinity with the writer's/director's taste in movies and artworks.

But regrettably, Mr. Vaughn Stein's script feels more like a handful of beautiful fragments of dialogue written on the back of envelopes and napkins over the years and haphazardly quilted into the above-mentioned movies; which results in a visually beautiful noir half baked idea, with good performances by Margot Robbie and Simon Pegg, that plagiarizes the storylines and characters of the works above mentioned, more than it pays hommage to them.
Script was so bad, it made everything hard to watch. Plot made no sense, even from an artistic standpoint. Visually amazing.

review_title: Doesn't deserve such a low score
review_detailed_main: Not the greatest movie but it doesn't deserve the low IMBD score or the poor reviews. It's entertaining and visually stunning if a tad slow paced. The acting is spot on and it has just enough twists to be interesting.

Terminal tells us an abstract and mysterious story that doesn´t take form until the last minutes in which, despite the few messages it manages to scatter haphazardly throughout itself, the attempt to twist the end as much as possible feels like a last-minute try to make sense of an ultimately aimless plot. This film catches you from beginning to end, with incredible performances, mesmerizing soundtrack and perfectly carried out stylistic elements. However, the lack of an actual story to tell makes us uncertain of what we've watched, by the end of it.

'Terminal' looks really good at first but the neon and overused shadow soon becomes tedious. Like the director is trying to dazzle you with flashy lights while hiding the total lack of substance in the mostly dark screen.

Editing and pacing are similarly ham-fisted but worst of all is the script: badly structured, ideas underdeveloped or overextended, dialogue mostly dreadful, and the denouements either stupidly obvious or stupidly far-fetched. It really is bad.

Margot Robbie is wonderfully watchable as always and Simon Pegg (cast against type) does well too, but they're working with material like a fifth former's fan fiction. Max Irons and Dexter Fletcher try hard and fail, though with even more dismal dialogue and, er, "plotline" it's really not their fault - unless you count them agreeing to be part of this in the first place.

Worst of all, however, is Mike Myers. Totally miscast, his presence creates even greater imbalance and telegraphs at least two of the twists. Nor has he the acting chops for a rather dark role; indeed his famous face and comedy CV suggests someone thought this was sort of blackly humorous piece.

It's not. Nor is it dramatic, or thrilling, or clever, or groundbreaking, or even a good homage to its embarrassingly obvious influences (Blade Runner, Sin City, etc). Nor does throwing in references to Lewis Carroll p4 Shakespeare quotes add intellectual heft.

No, all this amounts to is a monumental waste of money, talent and time.

review_title: I did not like anything, boring and predictable.
review_detailed_main:
It seems to me a movie without a soul, it is a movie that shows off the beauty of its protagonist, if you don't like it, don't watch it, it's a waste of time.

Of course, the protagonist is a true beauty.
Not to bad not to good and bit boring till the end...

So looks like the director is trying and failing to be like Guy Ritchie.. this movie is no where near paced nor as good as anything Ritchie has done. As far as entertaining, its not terrible. I only watched this for Simon Pegg. Margot Robbie is (IMO) not good in this.

This thang was keeping me entranced ALL the WAY!

I have always admired Dexter Fletcher. And with Margot Robbie as that 'bottle-blonde'! The cinematography was excellent! She is amazing with Simon Pegg! Another amazing writer/actor! I have loved his 'world' since my first exposure of Shaun Of The Dead! Even his work in the Star Trek production was mega Impressive! Terminal has a Drama about it that is odd to me... I AM convinced that the Soundtrack Music makes this movie float! (I always pronounce 'Robie' as 'Rowbee' it sounds better to say ' Margow Rowbee'! What an AMAZING aussie! That OST is EPIC!

This was a decent idea for a film, but it was just disappointing to watch. I won't repeat what other reviewers have said. I'll just say that the film dragged on for so long that it took all of the oomph out of the twists, especially because the twists were lazily developed to begin with. They were easy to guess not because the movie is full of clever clues that subtly point you to them but because they're the only logical explanation for some events and/or the set up is so blatant that it's hard not to see them coming. I really love being surprised by a good twist, but nothing in this movie surprised me. The script was a tortured parody of a Guy Ritchie film peppered with heavy-handed references to Alice In Wonderland, and half the time I just wanted the characters to shut up. I kind of liked the stylized design, but there was nothing unique about it. It just kept making me think of Sin City or Brazil.

It was worth the watch if only for Margot Robbie and Simon Pegg, whom I thought both delivered nice performances and whose scenes together were by far the most compelling. Tbh, you could've just plucked them out and made an excellent movie with just the two of them alone--although I like the idea of overlapping, semi-related stories taking place and coming together to provide a background for why everything is happening. I also like that it isn't obvious who exactly this film is about until the very end. But overall, I think it's too middle of the road, so it comes across as either trying too hard or not trying hard enough. I wish they had either a) kept it simple and forgone the overwrought script and most of the goofy atmospheric stuff in favor of something a tad bit more realistic or b) pushed it to the extreme and made it ten times more campy and crazy.

review_title: Amazing photography, but disappointing ending script
review_detailed_main: The photography and the style of this movie is amazing, perfecly executed. The acting is very good. The narrative, acting and photography style catches the attention, because they are in sync. The story is intringuing and ellaborated, but at the end it is quite disappointing The movie makes you expect more of the characters. There are three plot twists (all three hinted, but one still surprising). At the end there was one major plot flaw and a few disappointing expectations.

review_title: Like Eating a Bunch of Sparkling and Colorful Skittles
Don't let the poor reviews fool you
review_detailed_main:
This is one hell of a surprise. It's a stylised colour noir that breaths fun and happiness of filmmaking. Let's get this straight, noir is a specific genre, and a specific convention. If you expect a real, gritty, naturalistic approach you won't get it. So no point in watching this just so you can complain about. This is a fantasy story. It's graphic, and flamboyant. The acting is spot on, the cinematography is impeccable, the director has all narrative threads evolve and come together, nothing is forgotten and neglected.

The characters are typologies, are bigger than life, are in your face and so enjoyable constructed. Assassins, murders, crimes, light and shadow, guessing, always going forward; Grab a bag of popcorn, and enjoy some good ol' filmmaking

Very fine story, very fine actors. Too dark, too twisted, too strange. So, very much not my cup of tea.

But because of the excellent actors I'll rate this a 6.

I waited, and waited for this movie to get to me. But even after I'd finished it, I had to consult the internet to better understand the plot.

The acting is good, especially from Margot. But good acting couldn't even save this slow-paced movie.

I understand that some movies work well with slow build-ups, but at least make the finale worth the wait.

review_title: Too much talk, too little substance
review_detailed_main: The characters seem to love to talk and hear themselves talk but the result is a slow paced, drawn out story with not much happening much of the time and occasional violence for shock value. Could have been much better with a better script. Good cast wasted.

Whoever made this neo neon retro movie, was impressed by Pulp Fiction. The tongue-in-cheek attempts at cheeky humor are annoying. Tries to be surreal, but seems more contrived. Seen on Tubi, the free streaming site; which now has live TV.

review_title: A thriller that simply failed to materialize
review_detailed_main: What started off as an entertaining and witty dialogue between Bill (Simon Pegg) and Annie (Margot Robbie) with a promising plot, broke down to what can be described as a corny film with a lousy and shallow plot twist that doesn't leave the viewer with any sense of awe. As a matter of fact, all I felt by the last 30 minutes or so was utter disappointment. It was as if the writers had rushed to wrap up the script in order to meet a deadline. The rich and original performances of Pegg and Robbie, as well as the imaginative presentation of a neo-noir world (which can be credited to director Vaughn Stein and cinematographer Christopher Ross), were overshadowed by a dull twist of events. There were countless ways to go, but it seems everyone involved in the creative process of writing the script wanted to take the easy way out, and that just won't cut it.

Never saw such an immature, annoying, unoriginal and unengaging screenplay/direction since my days of film school back in 2008. All the recent reviews defending the movie are obviously posted by the director's circle of friends, if not himself.

review_title: there was a reason why it was cheaper.
review_detailed_main: I had heard nothing about this film,don't remember any reviews. I saw it in a dvd shop for 4 pounds less than other new dvds and bought it. There was a reason why it was cheaper,it is not very good. the good things about it are that it looks great. Fantastic neo noir neon lit sets. Margot Robbie is just beautiful in this and her acting is pretty good. But I did not enjoy the film much,it is a lot less clever and original than it thinks it is.

review_title: i'm laughing at all the pissy reviews; this flick was awesome!
review_detailed_main: Dark?, yes. visual?, yes. good cast?, fantastic. surprise ending?, indeed. soundtrack?, great. do yourself a favor and ignore all the negative reviews and give this a roll ... you won't regret it.

review_title: An entertaining film but not as good as it could have been.
review_detailed_main:
Just watched the film and it was okay. It's not terrible. One could say it has a personality, even if it's a little weird.

The set design, costume design and visuals of the movie are very good in their simplicity. They're the best thing in this movie along with the cinematography. The cast were all brilliant in their roles. The soundtrack is also really good. All these people did a great job.

Now, the dialogue was a bit pretentious and full of references, good at times but just awkward in others, in the end, it didn't blend well with the rest of the work. the editing was good and in others it made no sense, it could have been much better. the twists didn't really surprise me, there were hints over the whole movie that were easy to pick up on so i guess they failed in that too.

Overall, the movie clearly had a vision but it just feels dry and boring, it lacks that factor that pulls you in completely. But i still finished the whole thing so, they did an okay job. As a thriller it did what it had to do, thrill me. I just wish it did it better.

Maybe I'll change my mind next time I watch it but right now, this film is forgettable.

review_title: Messy, misjudged and, in the end, just quite boring.
review_detailed_main: 'Terminal (2018)' is just so messy and misjudged, relying on a bizarre and occasionally 'trailer-like' structure that often results in irreverently irrelevant plot-strands and a floaty feel that sees most moments slip by with an almost utter non-urgency. This leads to an experience that isn't engaging, often isn't pleasant and certainly isn't as clever as it clearly thinks it is. I'd cottoned on to its two biggest twists incredibly early on, while most of its other reveals come out of nowhere and don't really matter to the point they could be considered tangential at best and immaterial at worst, though certainly not surprising. On top of the generally abrasive characters and the lack of a proper driving force, there are some real problems with perspective. The picture often feels unsure as to whom it wants you to root for. When it finally makes up its mind about that, it seems confused as to why you ought to do so; really, it doesn't convey any compelling reasons for you to be engaged with anyone on screen. This leads to some bizarre and strangely unsettling sequences in which we're suddenly asked to change allegiances and excuse the cruel, almost sadistic behaviour of another character simply because we now know of their real motives, which doesn't do anything other than further distance us from the flick's core players and prove that the filmmakers don't really understand their own material - or, rather, the effect it will have on its audience. This is especially relevant as it pertains to who is the 'hero' and who is the 'villain', the indistinguishable nature of which would be a nice theme if it were explored properly and not cast aside for a last-minute revenge plot that asks us to root for, ostensibly, a text-book bad-guy just because the person they're hurting has done some bad things in the past. Let's not forget, however, that everyone in this dingy little piece has done terrible things on or off-screen at one point or another and that our 'protagonist' does stuff to rival most of it, no matter what their motivation is (I'm sure all the characters have had rough lives, by the way, it's no excuse). Overall, there are some interesting ideas and moments that have potential, but nothing ever comes to fruition and there's never any proper entertainment to be had. There aren't any genuine characters to invest in, things don't really pay off in a satisfying way and, when it comes down to it, it's not really all that enjoyable. In the end, it's just quite boring. 3/10
Please don't watch this you will waste an hour and a half of your life
Expectations was way to high before watching. The movie had good actors and twists here and there. But overall it was just okay

review_title: One of the worst movies I've ever seen
review_detailed_main:
About halfway through "Terminal," my wife turned to me and said "We can turn this off if you don't like it."

"No, let's keep going," I said. "If we stop now, I'm just going to wonder if we gave up just as it was about to get better."

Reader, it did not get better; in fact, it somehow managed to get worse. The story is confusing from the outset, though I initially assumed (too generously, it turns out) it was intentional: non-linear storytelling is a useful-if a bit overused-way to advance a story while slowly revealing everyone's roles within it. When it's done right, you get "Pulp Fiction"; even when it doesn't quite work, there's still some fun to be had in seeing how the writer pulls together all these disparate story arcs into one final act ("Lucky Number Slevin" comes to mind). With these labyrinthine plots, viewers will endure pretty much any amount of setup, as long as you make it worth their while in the end.

Trusting that it would be worth my while in the end, I sat through scene after scene of Margot Robbie trying to exude a perfect blend of mystery, danger and sex appeal. She does manage to strike that balance, in that she fails equally miserably at all three. With the notable exception of Bill (Simon Pegg in a customarily entertaining performance), the few breaks we do get from Robbie are no better: Vincent (Dexter Fletcher)'s irascibility is entertaining for the first few minutes, but quickly grows stale. His partner Alfred (Max Irons) serves little purpose beyond as a way to move the story on to the next scene. One minute he's human velvet, a suave, assured ladies' man; the next, he's salivating over strippers like he's never seen a (clothed) breast before. Even a good actor-say, for example, Max's father Jeremy-would struggle with a character this poorly-written. Max doesn't stand a chance. Mike Myers turns in a solid enough performance as Clinton, the night supervisor, though it's soured by some truly uninspired acting during the big reveal at the end.

I held out hope that my patience during the interminable middle acts would eventually be rewarded. It was in vain. Not only does "Terminal" fail to justify its plodding, self-indulgent existence, it almost does the opposite. About 3/4 of the way through, with practically zero warning, one character's horrific true nature is jarringly revealed; we barely have a chance to digest that information before *poof!* they're gone. At that point, the wheels truly come off, including a scene in which one character essentially admits to the viewer that an entire subplot of the film serves no purpose.

It all culminates in a "twist" ending that viewers will mostly see coming a mile off. There are a few elements of the climax that are truly surprising, but only because they're so unnecessary and, frankly, idiotic that it's genuinely astonishing that they ever made it past the first draft of the script, let alone into the final cut of the movie.

And then, mercifully, it ends. I only wish I'd throw in the towel when there was still something left of my night to salvage.

review_title: great cloudy mystery until the end
review_detailed_main: I was intrigued by the convoluted characters and weird actions and Robbie is central and eye candy. All the cast are well selected and do a great job. The setting is very much other worldly adding to the mystique and very much unclear in the beginning where the story is or where it is going. It took till over halfway thru that the action picked up in clearer direction but still not on target until the later part of the story fit all the pieces together and went well beyond early conceptions for a surprise ending. No need to listen to the bad comments -- I found it very enjoyable and well done. I rarely write reviews in IMBD but felt compelled here.

review_title: VIEWS ON FILM review of Terminal

review_detailed_main:
First I will say that this movie was not at all what I was expecting!

I saw this at the shops and thought of buying it, but decided to first look up and was convinced not to, as it didn't have the best rating (though I didn't read the reviews), though there are many movies that have low ratings, but I quite enjoy. I then saw it on Google Play Movies and, because there was a Black Friday special, decided to give it a go.

I was disappointed that I hadn't trusted my gut at the shops, but glad that I had rented it, as it sure didn't disappoint! Also, it has Mike Myers. What better actor?!

It was cast well and the visual effects... well, they were good. The plot was really good, though simple, but it could have been improved. The casting, though, was superb! I did find the accent that Margot Robbie put on a bit... it wasn't satisfying and a bit ditzy in the trailer, but I didn't mind it as the movie went on. The story was a little all over the place, but tied itself up quite nicely in the end with some twists, though, some of it was predictable.

All in all, I wasn't expecting much from this movie, but got a pleasant surprise with the final result! Would I recommend this? Yes, I sure would!
This movie is strange to say the least. If you like weird experiences, go for it. But beware. The ending may cause you confusion, vomit or the urge to punch the screen.

If one wants to create a clever, intriguing film, the general way to go about it is to write an exceptionally clever and intriguing plot. What "Terminal" has taught me is that there is a second way: take a typical and cliché story, put it into a blender, and dribble the story out in random, incoherent bits and pieces. That way, the audience is left guessing until the end as to what the heck is actually going on. Except that it appears many of us still figured it out by about 1/3 in.

"Terminal" has some interesting style and Simon Pegg and Margot Robbie are always highly watchable actors, so that (barely) got me through it. Unfortunately it was all wasted on a dull story.

What a fly infested bucket waste of the enormous talents of Robbie, Pegg and Fletcher. What were they thinking? (Of the finca farmhouse it bought them in Ibiza probs). DystopIan Beal nonsense garbage, supported by a frail 80 year old smoker walking home from Spoons strength plot of unintelligible, twerpish scenes and unoriginal transatlantic dirgealogue. After half an hour the build up of debris between my toes became more fascinating.

Terminal's strength is in its familiar elements: its dark, neon environment recalls "Blade Runner" and it plays like "Pulp Fiction". So if you like derivative films then you'll like, otherwise you'll criticize like most others here. The movie is unrated but I didn't see anything more than PG-13, and that's a further disappointment since Margot Robbie played a pole dancer at night and showed nothing, plus she's in short-order waitress wear most of the time, so further disappointment. The story itself is a double-cross revenger so no new ground broken there. Don't waste your "movie night" on this one, it's more one to play in the background while you're tablet-surfing or cleaning the living room.

No way this is a less than 6/10 movie just watched it and was expecting 7.5/10 at least on here?? Very strange!! I gave it 8/10 a bit different from your cgi super human x man, avenger type BS I suppose.

Dark, self-consciously quirky tale set in an anonymous city that succeeds in standing out from the crowd, but not always in a good way. Luscious femme-fatale Margot Robbie weaves a web around a bunch of hapless males, but the plot grows increasingly ludicrous, and seems to take forever to reach its conclusion.

review_title: Written like a somewhat talented school student's drama project on noir
review_detailed_main:
For a while, Terminal threatens to become a properly interesting and highly stylised psycho noir movie, but rapid disintegrates under the weight of cliche, unnecessary devices and simply awful writing. The dialogue and plot development feel like the cut scenes in a video game c2004. Most of the character reveals are entirely predicatable, the one that isn't is so silly and unnecessary as to be doubly irritating.

I admire directors and actors willing to take a risk and do something different, and I did genuinely like this up to a point, but in the end I'm simply amazed that such an ensemble of actors with plenty of opportunities to make better and/or better paying movies would sign on for this. OK, Dexter Fetcher and MIke Myers do exactly what they always do, but what on earth was Margot Robbie thinking?

review_title: Really hard to say what I think- form over substance saying nothing.
review_detailed_main:
The visuals are really stunning, colorful neon. Original? more Blade Runner vamped up to Neon fantasy, All form, no substance. there is no narrative, or little there that makes no sense. So dialogue that says nothing, scenes that make no sense. The end is disjointed. It is all meant to create an effect with nothing behind it. Rather than feel it is inventive or experimental, it seem to have an agenda to "surprise" and astound"'.

I have to think that the actors, like Simon and Mike, did their scenes without having an overall view, trusting that the film maker had a real vision (that worked). Some reviewers said there was a surprise ending with a twist- At the end I don't know what I was watching, it made no sense. It seemed the whole thing had no purpose, and nothing to say. so while it was trying to create an effect, definitely a fantasy, it was much ado about nothing. there seemed to be gratuitous violence (bloody) not even tied to a plot point. the end was supposed to some kind of reveal; it wasn't. "Revenge", I guess so.

in a weird way, it remembered me of "Last Year at Marienbad" the iconic French film by Renais. Because it was visually stunning, Last Year in black & white, without a narrative. Scenes that were evocative, but left you, the viewer uncertain. I got Renais' explanation after I watched it 3 times; he wanted to make a movie of pure emotion. Suddenly, it made sense. Like Abstract Motion Expressionist, Pollock, Frankenthaler, or totally non-objective. Kandinski.

Terminal fits the bill- but without the success. the 2 stars are for the stunning visual.

review_title: Tries too hard and fails harder

review_detailed_main: I like the actor/actress choices cast for the movie but this was pretty terrible. If anything surprises you, then I envy your never seeing a "thriller" before.
I thought I'd be dissatisfied by looking at the reviews but post watching this combo of actors I was left satisfied. Don't believe the negativity. I won't talk about movie I itself to not spoil it.

This movie looks cool and has an all-star and very talented cast (with the unfortunate exception of Mike Meyers who is still acting like he's in an Austin Powers sequel) and it all goes to waste with a plot that rarely surprises. There is much dialogue that thinks it's clever because it references worthy works of literature, tries to be pithy and uses British accents, but is mostly just boring and repetitive. Even Margot Robbie's beauty and considerable acting skills aren't enough for me to want her to keep talking about various ways to die.

The stylized noir look (read: lots of neon signs and the least daylight since 'Dark City') is cool for a while but by the end feels overused and makes it difficult to suspend disbelief. I felt like I was watching a continually hosed down set with a neon sign Snapchat filter as opposed to being taken into some cool fantasy world.

The plot is very straightforward and not original: hit men trying to kill each other. Emphasis on men being the idiots and doing the dying because it's PC to have a clever woman pulling the strings on dumb, good for nothing men being killed. What's annoying is that the story gets unnecessarily complicated not in service to the plot, but in service to its relentless pursuit of stylistic scenes with English Lit 101 quotations.

Maybe some people really did like this movie. Maybe style > substance or they were so smitten with Margot that they didn't care about the actual words coming out of her mouth. I'm not going to say don't watch this movie because maybe you will be one of the smitten and that's fine. For me it just wasn't all that compelling after I got over the eye candy treatment at about the 10 minute mark.

After watching Margot Robbie in I Tonya I added a bunch of her upcoming movies to my watchlist including this one. It's starts well with a hint of intrigue and then gets quite predictable and sloppy.

It is filmed and acted a little bit like a colourful Sin City. Margot acts pretty well but the script isn't really up to it. The villains are weak and it has a twist at the end that I saw coming from 10 minutes in.

I'm afraid you should give this movie a pass, there are many more better movies than this out there to kill 90 minutes.

review_title: British Harley Quinn, Tarantino's Pulp Fiction and Blade Runner.
review_detailed_main:
I really hope that this film will remain Vaughn Stein's last film writing experience.

Honestly, I suppose that they decided to start making the film like this: + Hey guys, you know Harley Quinn's tremendous fame after Suicide Squad, Why don't we shoot a solo film for her? But this time let's do something different.
What about making something like Pulp Fiction?
+ Yeah! Exactly.
Plus, I really love Blade Runner, let's add loads of neon-lighted scenes (I mean really loads)
+ Wait a minute, What about a screenplay?


I know it is too absurd but let's admit that it is absurd as much as the film. The first time I saw the trailer I thought that finally, we would see an amazing action film in 2018. Unfortunately, that didn't happen. The storytelling style and, indeed, the plot literally ruined the film. The film uses a lot of plot twists and shock reveals and I think the only reason made me watched the film to the end is that. To be honest, I am not a fan of Margot but I have to admit that she perfectly delivers her character and as always her evil smile is amazing.

Let me summarize. For the first 20 minutes, you say "it will be amazing" Between 20 and 60, you say "What the h**k did you do, Vaughn Stein? Okay, maybe I am overreacting, let's see what will happen at the end". Finally, at the end of the film, you say "Vaughn Stein, Look, buddy, just don't do it. Okay? Please, don't do this.

In the end, if you have enough time to watch lots of films, watch it. However, if you have little time. It will get your nerves at the end.

review_title: A Diabolical approach to "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There"

review_detailed_main: The prophetically titled "Terminal" is one of the worst movies in existence. It exemplifies everything wrong with post-nineties cinema. It is flashy, hollow, pretentious, vapid, meandering, obnoxious, smug, boring, stupid, and utterly pointless, which is not to suggest that the story isn't worth telling because there is no story. Literally. It's ninety-nine percent borrowed style and one percent Mike Myers, who embodies the worst casting decision since Mickey Rooney as Mr. Yunioshi. As for the rest of the cast, they are less a cast than three confused Englishmen who radiate a collective longing for the iconic, if merely competent, dialogue and direction of Guy Ritchie whilst a since matured Margot Robbie tries just a little too hard to steal their scenes. Scenes that ultimately amount to an inadvertent parody of the rapidly depreciating noire and cyberpunk sub-genres, and leaves you feeling simultaneously lobotomized and hit by a train.

I thought this is best movie but this is one of the flop movie ever . I don't advise you to watch this movie. Dont watch this movie 🍿🎥 and waste your time. The movie was an utter disappointment. Its plot felt scattered, lacking cohesion, leaving gaping holes that made it hard to follow. The characters were one-dimensional, failing to evoke any emotional investment. The acting felt forced, devoid of authenticity. Additionally, the cinematography was uninspiring, offering nothing visually stimulating. Overall, a forgettable experience that fell far short of expectations.one of the folp movie ever.

Eye-pleasing cinematography, stylish design, and a charming performance by the lovely Margot Robbie are all high points for Terminal, though I'm afraid these positives are still not enough to save it from its narrative mediocrity. Much of the film is an attractive, convoluted mess; the final bit at least pulls it all together in a way that helps it make a lot more sense, but its reasoning still feels like a reach. I'm sort of left wondering why...what was the point of this film's creation? If it exists only to flex its superb style and colors, then I suppose they deserve a 5.5/10; if it's attempting something more, then I'd rate it something less. I'll assume the former.

I enjoyed this movie. It was kind of confusing in the beginning as I was not sure what was happening. This is the kind of movies I like. Mysterious and unpredictable. I was extremely happy with the ending. I like unexpected endings.

I really enjoyed this film at the get go, but was left feeling betrayed by a predictable conclusion. There was some clever dialogue and wit through the first half of the movie. Margot Robbie really is a remarkable actress especially when playing emotional unstable characters and Simon Pegg puts in a terrificly solemn performance as a dying school teacher.

Unfortunately the moment of discovery is rushed and poorly done. The plot twist is so thinly veiled that I had hoped for some other more clever back story that might save it, but there was none. What had the promises of a clever and well acted movie flamed out all too abruptly.

Overall a letdown.
If this movie was filmed in a 2:35:1 widescreen, then why would they put out a 1:85:1 widescreen version when they released the DVD?

review_title: Boring with a few bright spots...
review_detailed_main: I love Simon Pegg and Margot Robbie...but this is far from their best work. Not that they were the bad part, it just wasn't interesting. I could tell what they were going for, but it just wasn't exciting or visually interesting. I almost stopped at half way but it picked up a tiny bit.
Simone pegg was xxxxx brilliant in this movie. What a superstar

review_title: Are people starting to have preconceived notion prior to watching a film these days?
review_detailed_main: Everyone is beginning to expect too much. Yes holleywood has raised the bar with lots of movies recently and boy has it been a treat. But I fear our expectations are outgrowing our imagination and our love for simply being entertained. This movie for me does just that. It is highly entertaining. Noir films for me are especially special treat due to my dark sense of humor. I originally gave this film an 8. But after reading the reviews and seeing all the negativity and all the 1's. (Which reminds me how does any movie deserve a 1? There's always some redeemable quality in a movie that should at least give it an automatic 2 or above, unless it's sharknado!) I decided to turn my vote into a 10. It's unbelievable how many haters there are. Stop watching CNN!!!

review_title: 3 levels of messages. Stylistically crisp. Needs a few viewings to actually get to the bottom of this.
review_detailed_main: So much more here than you originally know. Enjoyable on several levels.

review_title: Cockney neon noir is a stunning visual confection
review_detailed_main: You have to be patient with the first half of this movie. And if if British cockney banter is not your cup of tea you will struggle. Simon Pegg adds formidable balance to that aspect, but you'll still need to be patient. Luckily in the competent hands of a really good script and some very able actors that shouldn't be a problem, particularly if you are admiring the perfect moody late night lighting, which moves from city vista to echoing spooky corridors, to platforms, and to dead end rooms that nod to the 1950s. I wasn't kidding when I described this as neon noir. A splendour worth beholding (they use really good cameras). And.... if you happen to be a literary fan of Alice In Wonderland, the cockney prose will probably tickle as well (I'm not such a fan, but that didn't seem to hurt my enjoyment, in fact, such references seemed to be a perfect spice). I liked the camera angles and frames, and the way at odd times they tried something different. Good editing I thought. The characterisations are excellent, but not groundbreakingly original, save the Mike Meyers character. They are at least perfectly cast. You'll probably guess what is going on but that probably won't spoil your movie. It's the sort of movie where they give so many clues away anyway that I think they allow for that, and it shouldn't spoil anything (you probably won't get it entirely). For me, Terminal needed something truely brutal to open the proceedings, and could have done with some beginning narration. Given the Alice references that seemed to me to be something that would have worked, but that's me. Certainly Terminal is an accomplished piece of modern noir artistry, and is well worth a look.

review_title: Some might say it started with a slow burn but it has a dynamite ending
review_detailed_main:
It started off a bit slow for me. I did enjoy the cinematography and the music, very well done. The script was interesting and witty.

It did seem like it was a bit disjointed the first hour but the last 30 minutes and the ending are a blast and I don't want to give away how it brings together what you saw previously.

It reminds me of 'The Usual Suspects' (1995) a favorite of mine but done in its own unique way.

review_title: I can not believe this negative useless reviews
review_detailed_main: The film has some great actors in this. The plot is dark Has many twist to it.And may bewilder a simple mind ! Margot Robbie was excellent in this as the string puller .Highly recommend

I seldom write reviews, however the poor ratings make me stop and pause. The banter between characters was witty and added a nuance to the story. I thought the use of the light and neon highly stylized the point of the movie. It reminded me of Sin City or Snatch. Very enjoyable and my kind noir.
I don't even see why this movie has negative reviews. This movie was brilliant

review_title: The most people do not understand what movie is about, this movie is great.

If you give professional movie critics and gave this movie a 6 or below you don't have any knowledge about movies.

GET ANOTHER JOB!

A good movie doesn't always have to be an over-acted drama.

I'm really annoyed by those professional critics.

review_title: Incredible film noir for our time
review_detailed_main: What a film! Visually so stunning you can't look away. Margot Robbie is enthralling as Annie and the whole cast give incredibly accomplished performances. Vaughn Stein's direction is intelligent and interesting. The twists were unexpected. Would highly recommend. A new classic film noir.
Sleeper. Intriguing. Visually appealing. Slow burn but worth it. I enjoyed the cinematography and use of color. Dialogue reminiscent of stories from a good book. Likely not for everyone.

People putting bad reviews are the corrupted ones raised with next gen CGI and who expect movies to be all the same (Marvel's anyone?). I don't even understand why people would expect this to be a sci-fi movie, and badly review it for not being like star wars... If you like the movie and think it doesn't deserve a 5 or less, review it with a ten to counter the hate toward the non carbon copy of the movie the kids were expecting to see before reviewing it. The story is great if you do not have the attention span of a goldfish, and even if it could have been better in some aspect it is still great. Don't hate, watch it, enjoy it.

review_title: An abundance of style, substance and talent
review_detailed_main:
Terminal (2018) is a very stylish and stylized film with a talented cast, a very intelligent script, a Byzantine plot, numerous allusions to works by Quentin Tarantino and Lewis Carroll, and a surprise ending. The cinematography is great, with a lot of texture and vibrant colors that pop out of the murky shadows and a refreshing paucity of jiggly-cam shots. The film is minimalist, with five main characters and three primary locations for most of the action. It is not without its faults. It definitely doesn't start with a bang, but builds to a simmer that can test the patience. The plot is a bit contrived. Between the plot contrivances and the highly-stylized imagery, it is difficult to suspend disbelief. The violence isn't far removed from what might pass for primetime network fare and the sex is 99 44/100ths percent suggestion, with nothing steamier than a few passionate kisses and a visit to that strip club in the land of mid-American television fantasy, where the dancers are nice girls who don't remove their clothes. It is a bit like There Shape of Water (2017), which I confess, I haven't actually managed to finish viewing. It's very beautiful and an impressive achievement, but the style is more accessible than the substance.

However, the performances are quite good. I found myself engaged with each of the five main characters. There are enough subtle elements, that one will want to view the film again to appreciate the allusions that may have escaped notice on the first viewing.

I loved this movie. I don't tend to read reviews (although sometimes the star rating on Amazon tends to influence my decision to watch). The movie came up as a recommendation on my Amazon Prime/Video page so I gave it a go and was very glad I did. It is very surreal, very 'noir' and has many twists and turns in the plot. It also has a cracking cast! It feels a lot like a cinematic adaptation of a stage play too - maybe one day we'll see it on stage...? who knows! Anyway, big thumbs up from me.

Worth a watch; particularly for a British audience or those bored of the standard, predictable Hollywood guff being mercilessly turfed out and peddled as if it's new or brilliant. This actually has a developing storyline with some epic twists and a violence throughout which is justified. The New York Times et Al. don't have the intellect to understand it but if you're looking for something genuinely different, exciting and twisting; definitely give it a go.
A very well done movie. Alfred Hitchcock like. Twist after twist. Definitely recommended.

review_title: Who said mystery is a lost art?

review_detailed_main: This was a great movie! I completely disagree with the critics. I made an IMDB account just to leave a review for this movie. I thought it was engaging, interesting and definetly worth an hour and a half of my time. If you like clockwork orange or pulp fiction I think you will like this too. Though they are very different I would say it has the same feel at points throughout the movie.

Good cult classic. If you're a fan of assassin films or Alice in wonderland or film noire films chances are you'll enjoy.

Easily going to be a marmite film.

Good plot twists - some more obvious than others. Most easily guessed - either myself or my husband figured all out (with disagreements on some here or there)

Margot Robbie and Simon Peggy build a great standing point and while it does give Harley vibes - any insanity / violent Margot Robbie film know is going to and it isn't an exact Harley feel. And she plays it well.

Good British films will typical British accents which always work out well.

Sin city vs malice in wonderland vibes only missing Danny dyer.

review_title: Down the rabbit hole to noir nirvana
Margot Said That This Is Unique..And yeah..she said the truth..
review_detailed_main: It is a thrilling mystery fullfilled with crime..a great story..you need to concentrate so you never miss a detail..it's a 'small details matter' type of film..and Margot is just Amazing..she did a great job..You Gotta Watch it!

review_title: 8/10 really but wanted to bolster the unfair rating
review_detailed_main: Interesting, well acted, different, classy, dark, shall I go on? It's not a master piece but 90 minutes we'll spent. All 4 main characters are interesting and extremely well played. How anyone could score it 1/10 is beyond me
All the negativity I've read nearly put me off. I'm glad I don't always believe what I read. I really did enjoy this film, maybe my humour is equally as dark. Giggled instead of yawning.

The first thing that you notice is how visually stunning this film is, the whole cast is fantastic and there really wasn't one bad performance. Margot robbie took up the whole screen in every scene she was in, not just a pretty face, her acting is mesmerizing. Why the "critics" panned this is beyond me, maybe we need different critics whose job statement just doesn't require them to harshly critique a film just to appear more intelligent.....

review_title: This is the British Quentin Tarantino, you idiots!
review_detailed_main: Brilliant! Colorful! Clever! A piece of ART!!! I highly recommend it to all of you who have many years to see a good movie! (I can't believe the negative reviews, many shallow critiques by people who clearly know nothing about movie making and film art!)
This is a classic double cross, shady, cheeky, "naughty" kind of movie. Cracking Sunday night movie or time filler. Don't understand why it's been given such a low rating. Try it for yourself
Great movie. Dont listen to idiots who think they know how a neo noir movie should go. Maybe these reviews are American. Give it a go. Plot twists, beautiful lighting and Margot looking epic.
And with that one line, I was sold on a movie. Darkness, depravity, the blackest of humour and Margot Robbie in snake-seamed stockings.

Well knowing nothing more than the short summary over Netflix I skipped over it quite a bit. I just had a feeling it could be great but wouldn't be... turns out it was pretty damn good. I'd say just watch it, it wasn't until after I watched it that I saw these terrible reviews but I must say it was a great story and visually stunning.

review_title: Clever story. Beautifully shot. Great movie
review_detailed_main: Cinematography is superb. Clever twisty tale. Wonderful cast ensemble. If you like smart movies, you'll get this. The neg reviews represent the reviewers incapacity to view an art form objectively and interpret the concept as not how they would have done it. I suppose I have done the same.

Although I understand that the majority of reviews are based on personal perceptions, I dind't understood the hate.

Solid actings in an awesome dystopic "neon" world; oustanding visuals and photograph;, striking locations; mesmerizing OST and a good script well executed.

What is there not to love about it?

I'm giving this a 10, because the bad reviews need to be balanced out. It's a solid 7 at heart, people on here love the smell of their own farts and really like to hear themselves talk. Give it a watch, it does give nods to a lot of different films and was entertaining enough for a single watch maybe a second one, nothing that will blow your mind. Margot does it the justice as she always does.
How can films such as Chef (0/10) receive 7.3 and this 5.3? This is a truly interesting film with a great plot and fantastic acting.

This is a really strange film. I'd not heard anything about it until it popped up on Amazon Prime, so went into it with no expectations or any of the critics' mallings.

The plot is a fairly convention cross-and-double cross thriller. Dispensing with action sequences, it's driven by dialogue and some quite compelling performances. Everything is stripped back to focus on just a handful of characters and simple sets.

There are quirky shots, a thread that becomes more apparent as the story progresses and Margot Robbie gives it her all. The scenes between her and Simon Pegg as they discuss life and suicide are fascinating.

It's not perfect - the end is a little hurried - but it's worth watching. Particularly if you enjoy quirky dialogue and characters.

review_title: Boring at first but full of incredible plot twists at the end

I was weary of some of the poor reviews but thought the cast and premise looked too good for it to be that bad. What a wonderful surprise that this film was such a delight. It builds slowly with some long scenes but they are gripping as the dialogue and characters are so interesting. As the plot builds and then things really take off in the second half, it just gets better and better. Margot Robbie, Dexter Fletcher and Simon Pegg are standout performers in this but the way that the story develops and comes to a climax just when you are ready for it makes this a very rare 10/10 for me. Add to that a great but dark soundtrack by Newton Faulkner and this is a future classic.

If you like plot twist movies, you should like this - especially if you like any of the actors in this movie which is why I watched it! I was NOT disappointed! 😍

review_title: THE PLOT TWIST/ DC VIBE WAS EVERYTHING

review_detailed_main: I can understand why some people didn't like this movie; they expected to see Lost in Space or something to that effect. Terminal is a dark (literally), off-the-wall, eccentric, European movie that plays on mood and ambience. The colours are strong and vivid. The actors are superb - especially Margot Robbie. While I was never a Mike Myers fan, his role here was an eye-opener. An excellently paced and shot movie that I'll watch many times over.
A very good movie ! I was impressed . The dialogue is excelent and the actors are the best ! I really liked it . I don't understand is this movie so low rated

This is a film that is too well done, inventive and thrilling for it to have such awful ratings. I really can't understand it. I swear that I've seen a lot of movies and I can easily recognize a crappy one. The remake of Fantastic 4 is one of them, the overrated "thriller" film called The Dinner is also one of them, as well as Baywatch, The Mummy (another remake), Dead Silence, Batman V Superman...those are crappy movies. But not this one.

When you watch the trailer of 'Terminal', the first thing you think it's that the movie is a complete mess with no logic, story or sense. And when I went to see it at the cinema, I was already prepared for that possiblility and with only one reason for watching it: Margot Robbie.

But turns out that I was completely wrong. It is an excellent thriller with a great visual neon-like style, very good acting from everyone (Robbie was magnificent and her character gets more scary as the film progresses), excellent script with tones of black humor (my favorite), shocking plot twists and a final act that leaves you with the open mouth.

Enjoy!

10/10

review_title: I don't understand the dislike for this stellar movie.

review_detailed_main: Beautifully done, filled with metaphors, artistic and literature references, this movie is for anyone but not everyone

Reviews mostly are either 1, 2, or 3 stars or 8, 9, 10 stars so you either love it or hate it. Curiouser & curiouser cries Alice, and like the script of Terminal which had some references to Alice in Wonderland it too was filled w/double entendres (figuratively & literally similar to the excellent series Orphan Black), metaphor, foreshadowing, allusion, situational irony. Dialogue where "pathetic fallacy" is presented (that is rare) as in this situational dilemma "emotional turmoil is reflected in tangible surrounds". Which then proceeds to the choice of "gravity or gravitas". Lighting and settings that reminded me of the original Blade Runner. Script had elements of classical film noir. Lighting, camera angles, props, clothing, makeup, sound effects all creatively presented unlike the mass produced formula robotic look-alike films being fast food produced. Endings, yes there were more than one - most all unexpected. Summing up - basically an intelligent sensory experience.

'Nuff said. Just pick up a DVD. If you're disappointed, sue me!

review_title: In my top favorite movies list!
review_detailed_main:
Upon watching this the first time, I'd purely started it to entangle myself in Margot Robbies excellent films and become more familiar with her acting.

However, the neon aesthetic and run down, criminalized set up of the world they build left me breath taken.

The storyline is one of those that leave you asking questions halfway through, but then take all those stray strings and tie them into one perfect knot.

The thrilling feeling of this perfect, masterful writing was enough to make me squirm in my seat! The set up, and the climax was incredibly appealing.

Not just that, but the acting and the chemistry of all the actors feels perfectly natural. There are moments I find myself forgetting that most of them had probably not ever met before this film.

The only downside is that they present a fantastical dystopian world that they hardly explore. I think at the end of the movie, there's room for another film focusing on other alice n wonderland related characters to further build this crime based city.

Ignore the reviews that tear down the directors writing ability. There really is beautiful storytelling in this film and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys movies that make you theorize. This movie is very similar to Quentin Tarantinos writing.

review_title: Of shoes--and ships--and sealing-wax--Of cabbages--and kings
review_detailed_main: I really enjoyed this, though it was hard to follow at times! Margot Robbie is so beautiful, painfully so! And she does a good job acting too! Mike Myers also turns in a good performance, as does Simon Pegg! Lots of twists, lots of timeline shifts. Dark and colorful at the same time, making it a bit surreal. And many, many Alice in Wonderland references. Confusing and entertaining!

review_title: I just wanted to take a look to see if I wanted to watch it.
review_detailed_main: By the time I decided I was going to watch the film the twins were leaving the terminal and they were rolling the credits. I was just going to give it a peak to see if it was worth watching. I couldn't take my eyes away once I started watching because the story, seemingly obscure and a bit all over the place, was compelling and works in this situation. It's like watching a Frank Miller film like Sin City, with ever changing surroundings and plot twists that invariably take you through the full gamut of intertwined lives and stories, to it's inevitable conclusion. At the end, the entire film made sense and I was left amazed how fluid this confusing story actually was. The jumping around is deliberate and without it this film would have been boring, to say the least. I, for one, really enjoyed this film and without Margo Robbie as the titular psychopath with her expressive face that rolls easily from demure to psychotic, without missing a beat. Many people said they didn't like the film, and with some this is a kind way of saying how much they hated it. As a viewer, not a critic with my head in a dark place praising my cinematic knowledge, I enjoyed this film and I think it got a bad rep from people that set the bar way too high for this film noir. This film doesn't leave any loose ends, and leaves you satisfied that there were no secrets that the director left out, or added, that made no sense, like so many quick cut and run movies out today. I hope this film, not movie, makes some money in after theater sales, it deserves it.

review_title: A slow burner that's well worth the ride!
review_detailed_main:
I watched this film, mainly as a Simon Pegg fan. I didn't really know what to expect and, to be fair, given the low score on here; I expected very little.

Thankfully I found a gem. Margot Robbie is deliciously dark and mysterious, Simon Pegg is subtlety brilliant and Mike Myers is perfectly nuts. The entire cast is perfect actually!

The terminal has a very dark comedic feel and is very stylish from start to finish. It reminded me of Guy Ritchie's direction at times and it took me a good while before the pieces of the story started to fall into place properly. But when everything did fall into place is was so satisfying, although maybe not completely surprising on all counts.

Don't miss this one because of the low score. Terminal is well worth your time and turns out to be a solid 8/10 movie for me.
